statement.p: Explain why the vectors \left[\begin{array}{r} 4 \\ -2 \\ -2 \\ 0 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 1 \\ 3 \\ -2 \\ 3 \\ 3 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 1 \\ -1 \\ 0 \\ -3 \\ -3 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 6 \\ 0 \\ -4 \\ 0 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] , \text{ and } \left[\begin{array}{r} 13 \\ -7 \\ -6 \\ -3 \\ 3 \end{array}\right] are or are not a basis of \mathbb{R}^5

answer.p: The vectors \left[\begin{array}{r} 4 \\ -2 \\ -2 \\ 0 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 1 \\ 3 \\ -2 \\ 3 \\ 3 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 1 \\ -1 \\ 0 \\ -3 \\ -3 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 6 \\ 0 \\ -4 \\ 0 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] , \text{ and } \left[\begin{array}{r} 13 \\ -7 \\ -6 \\ -3 \\ 3 \end{array}\right] are not a basis of \mathbb{R}^5.
